info.game_comments:
Jackie Harrison game 1.

(Jimmy: I'm scrimmaging with the Pittsburgh Steelers.)
(Charlie Batch: Hey Mark, let's go a little easy on Jimmy!)
(Mark Bruener: You know he's a little man; why don't we play two-handed touch?)
(Jimmy: Football clues coming up next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: First planted in Brazil around 1727, by the 19th century it was the country's top export

(2, 1).clue: 405 miles but only 2 letters long, this Italian river flows past Turin, Cremona & Ferrara

(3, 1).clue: The poblano type of these is popular when making them rellenos, or stuffed

(4, 1).clue: This Egyptian canine spends his day around Lake Nasser

(5, 1).clue: The theme of Raj Kapoor's "Ram Teri Ganga Maili" is the pollution of this river

(6, 1).clue: The London Underground is also called this

(1, 2).clue: 23 years after the United States did so, Brazil abolished this in 1888

(2, 2).clue: The east coast Italian cities of Rimini & Bari are found on this sea, an arm of the Mediterranean

(3, 2).clue: Author Diana Kennedy says, "Always serve a wedge of" this dessert "with plenty of the extra syrup"

(4, 2).clue: In Aug., thousands of these birds stop in Egypt on their migration to South Africa; that's a lot of baby deliveries!

(5, 2).clue: "Rajah Harishandra", India's first full-length story film, premiered in 1913 in this city, a future film center

(6, 2).clue: This show that originated on the BBC features Tinky Winky & Laa-Laa

(1, 3).clue: This dance was popular for decades in Brazil before achieving popularity in the U.S. around 1930

(2, 3).clue: A 7-mile tunnel through this mountain peak connects Italy to Chamonix, France

(3, 3).clue: You can make the traditional ties for these from strands of their corn husk wrappings

(4, 3).clue: A close relative of the wild goat, this Egyptian mammal's name would be great for an "ENDS IN X" category

(5, 3).clue: India's 1st talkie, 1931's "Alam Ara", began a pattern of stopping the action for an often irrelevant one of these

(6, 3).clue: E.H. Baily's 17-foot-tall statue of Lord Nelson is in this London plaza

(1, 4).clue: South America's most populous city, it was founded by Jesuit priests in 1554

(2, 4).clue: The play "Much Ado About Nothing" takes place in the port city of Messina on this Italian island

(3, 4).clue: Cochinita pibil, a classic Yucatan dish, is one of these cooked in a pib, or pit

(4, 4).clue: The fennec, Vulpes zerda, is also called the "desert" type of this

(5, 4).clue: Before he teamed up with Ivory, he directed the Oscar-nominated Indian short "The Creation of a Woman"

(6, 4).clue: It rises in Gloucestershire, near Cheltenham

(2, 5).clue: In 1861 this 9,300-square-mile island just south of Corsica became a part of the kingdom of Italy

(3, 5).clue: The name of this chopped fruit relish means "rooster's beak"

(4, 5).clue: These fish-eating falcons populate Egyptian coastal areas like the Gulf of Aqaba

(5, 5).clue: This 2001 film is about the chaos surrounding an arranged marriage in the Verma family

(6, 5).clue: 4 museums in England that house national collections bear the name of this sugar magnate

(1, 1).clue: This author's "The Bear" is one of many stories dealing with the McCaslins of Yoknapatawpha County

(2, 1).clue: (Mark Bruener of the Pittsburgh Steelers gives the clue, along with Jimmy of the Clue Crew.)  I'm holding Jimmy off with this maneuver, like the Heisman Trophy statue

(3, 1).clue: 3-letter word for the type of piece for which Scott Joplin is best known

(5, 1).clue: In 2000 Gao Xingjian became the first writer from this country to win the Nobel Prize for Literature

(6, 1).clue: TV show in which E.B. White's mouse-like boy lives with Laura Ingalls & her pa
(6, 1).correct response: Stuart Little House on the Prairie

(1, 2).clue: It's said that this "Tom Jones" author (mistakenly) traced his lineage to the Hapsburgs

(2, 2).clue: 49ers coach Red Hickey pioneered this formation with the quarterback a few yards behind the center

(3, 2).clue: Mozart's Sonata in F Major, Kochel No. 497, is for 1 piano played with 4 of these

(5, 2).clue: He was teaching at the University of Chicago when he won the 1976 Nobel Prize in Economics

(6, 2).clue: Bionic "Six Million Dollar Man of Mystery" whose foe is Dr. Evil

(1, 3).clue: Books based on his BBC Radio lectures during WWII include "The Screwtape Letters" & "Mere Christianity"

(2, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew giving the clue, accompanied by Charlie Batch of the Pittsburgh Steelers)  It's said the great Jim Thorpe could kick 50-yard field goals using this style of kick no longer used

(3, 3).clue: The Brahms work heard here is this type of dance music

(4, 3).clue: Ale maker in England sold to Coors in February 2002

(5, 3).clue: In 1943 the Nobel assembly gave a dam, Henrik Dam, a prize for discovering this vitamin which aids in blood clotting

(6, 3).clue: Sergio Leone & Hans Christian Andersen Spaghetti Western in which Clint Eastwood becomes a swan
(6, 3).correct response: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly Duckling

(1, 4).clue: This author of "The House of Spirits" once worked for the U.N.'s food & agriculture organization

(2, 4).clue: The 3-4 defense is named for its alignment of 3 linemen & 4 of these

(3, 4).clue: This 19th century composer's Opus 14 is classified as a Krakowiak

(5, 4).clue: Willard Libby won a Chemistry prize for his method of using this radioactive isotope to date fossils & other objects

(6, 4).clue: "Super Freak" singer who authored the "Leatherstocking Tales"

(1, 5).clue: He led a marine biology expedition to Baja California & later wrote about it in "The Sea of Cortez"

(2, 5).clue: (Charlie Batch giving the clue, along with Mark Bruener & Jimmy)  It's a trick play that includes the name of a dog pest

(3, 5).clue: Also a word for a daydream, Schumann wrote one in C Major in 1836

(4, 5).clue: Long wooden spear used by medieval foot soldiers

(5, 5).clue: It doesn't take a nuclear physicist to figure out that he won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize

(6, 5).clue: Haley Joel Osment's catchphrase from "The Sixth Sense" that was a "weird" 1967 Doors song
(6, 5).correct response: I see dead People are Strange

(0, 0).clue: In June 1885 it made a historic transatlantic voyage in 214 crates on the frigate Isere
